paper_id: Nutrient Partitioning and Stoichiometry in Unburnt Sugarcane Ratoon at Varying Yield Levels

paper_metadata.title: Nutrient Partitioning and Stoichiometry in Unburnt Sugarcane Ratoon at Varying Yield Levels

authors.name: José M. Leite
authors.affiliation: Department of Soil Science, University of São Paulo, Piracicaba, Brazil

authors.name: Ignacio A. Ciampitti
authors.affiliation: Department of Agronomy, Kansas State University, Manhattan, KS, USA

authors.name: Eduardo Mariano
authors.affiliation: Laboratory of Stable Isotopes, University of São Paulo, Piracicaba, Brazil

authors.name: Michele X. Vieira-Megda
authors.affiliation: Department of Agriculture, State University of Montes Claros, Janaúba, Brazil

authors.name: Paulo C. O. Trivelin
authors.affiliation: Laboratory of Stable Isotopes, University of São Paulo, Piracicaba, Brazil

paper_metadata.study_region: Southeast region of Brazil (São Paulo state)
paper_metadata.primary_focus: Investigation of biomass and nutrient (N, P, K) content, partitioning, stoichiometry, and internal efficiencies in sugarcane ratoon at varying yield levels under green cane management.

research_methodology.experimental_design: Randomized complete block design with varying treatments and replications across three sites.

temporal_scope.data_collection_frequency: Four sampling times throughout the ratoon season; biweekly weather data collection.
temporal_scope.seasonal_coverage: Full sugarcane growing season (equivalent to 12 months) for first ratoon cycle.
monitoring_timeline: Site 1: 2009/2010 growing season (Plant cane harvested May 2009 at 433 DAP, treatments applied September 2009, sampling at 139, 178, 235, 330 DAH)
Site 2: 2009/2010 growing season (Plant cane harvested June 2009 at 456 DAP, treatments applied October 2009, sampling at 133, 170, 227, 331 DAH)
Site 3: 2012/2013 growing season (Plant cane harvested August 2012 at 442 DAP, treatments applied October 2012, sampling at 145, 198, 290, 380 DAH)

spatial_scope.geographic_coverage: State of São Paulo, Southeast region of Brazil.
site_characteristics: Conventional tillage (plowing, disking, harrowing, furrowing) every 6 years
Soil correction (lime and gypsum) every 6 years
Green cane management system (mechanical harvest, residues left on soil surface)
spatial_scope.coordinates: Site 1: Piracicaba (22° 35′ S; 47° 37′ W); Site 2: Santa Cruz das Palmeiras (21° 47′ S; 47° 11′ W); Site 3: Severínia (20° 46′ S; 48° 45′ W)
spatial_scope.regional_representativeness: Covers different soil types (Typic Hapludox, Typic Eutrustox) within the major sugarcane producing region of Brazil.

sample_sizes.soil_sampling_per_block: 4 composite samples (9 individual samples each) at 20-cm intervals until 100-cm depth

controls_and_treatments: Site 1: Fertilizer N sources (ammonium chloride, ammonium nitrate, calcium ammonium nitrate, organo-mineral fertilizer, urea, and control (no-N added)), applied at a rate of 100 kg N ha⁻¹. Total of 6 treatments. 75 kg K ha⁻¹ applied.

Site 2: Fertilizer N sources (ammonium chloride, ammonium nitrate, calcium ammonium nitrate, organo-mineral fertilizer, urea, ammonium sulfate, and control (no-N added)), applied at a rate of 100 kg N ha⁻¹. Total of 7 treatments. 125 kg K ha⁻¹ and 15 kg P ha⁻¹ applied.
Site 3: Rates of humic substances solution (HSS) (115, 230, 460 kg HSS ha⁻¹), N (25, 50, 100 kg N ha⁻¹), and HSS+N interactions; control (no HSS/N). Total of 10 treatments.
sample_design.statistical_power: Not explicitly stated, but n=102 for overall analysis suggests reasonable power.

measurement_protocols: Soil pH: 0.01 mol L⁻¹ CaCl₂ (1:2.5 soil:solution)
Soil organic C: Wet oxidation (Walkley–Black procedure)
Available P, K, Ca, Mg: Ion-exchange resins extraction
Ca, Mg quantification: Atomic absorption spectroscopic
CEC at pH 7.0: Summation of exchangeable cations (K, Ca, Mg) and potential acidity (H + Al)
Total N in plant tissues: Steam distillation (Kjeldahl)
Total P in plant tissues: Gravimetry
Total K in plant tissues: Flame emission photometry
quality_control: Plant tissue analysis followed AOAC International (2006) official methods, specifically for total N (Kjeldahl), P (gravimetry), and K (flame emission photometry).

analysis_methods: Descriptive statistics (mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, 25–75% quartile)
Non-linear regressions (Sigmoid equation for biomass accumulation, Gaussian equation for nutrient partitioning)
Relationship assessment between sugarcane yield and nutrient content
statistical_approach.uncertainty_quantification: Standard deviation (SD) reported for all descriptive statistics.
statistical_approach.model_validation: Models validated using previously published studies (Shukla et al., 2009; Oliveira et al., 2010; Schultz et al., 2010) to demonstrate fitness and robustness.

primary_measurements.measurement_context: Estimated based on fresh matter of stalks collected from 3-m plant row in the last sampling date.
Summation of all plant components (stalks, dry leaves, tops) collected in each sampling date.
Total N in aboveground plant fraction.
Total P in aboveground plant fraction.
Total K in aboveground plant fraction.
Average across sites for N, P, and K respectively.
Stalks to aboveground biomass ratio (dry weight) at last sampling date.
N content in stalk relative to total N in aboveground plant fraction.
P content in stalk relative to total P in aboveground plant fraction.
K content in stalk relative to total K in aboveground plant fraction.

statistical_relationships.effect_size: Aboveground N:P ratio ~6:1; Dry leaves N:P ratio ~18:1; Tops N:P ratio ~6:1; Stalk N:P ratio ~4:1. High-yielding sugarcane related to narrowed N:P ratio (6:1) in tops.
Overall N:K ratio ~0.5:1 (range 0.1:1 to 1.2:1). High-yielding sugarcane related to more balanced N:K (0.5:1).

temporal_patterns.trend_description: Sigmoid pattern with three distinct growth phases.
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: Phase I (lag): ~0-135 DAH (0-1450 °C GDDs), ~10% final biomass. Phase II (exponential–linear): ~135-270 DAH (1450-2800 °C GDDs), ~65% final biomass. Phase III (stationary): ~270-370 DAH (2800-4000 °C GDDs), ~25% final biomass.

temporal_patterns.trend_description: 50% of total N, P, K content occurred earlier than 50% of biomass accumulation.
temporal_patterns.seasonal_component: 50% N at 212 DAH (2259 GDDs), 50% P at 209 DAH (2292 GDDs), 50% K at 214 DAH (2314 GDDs). Asynchrony of ~38 days compared to 50% biomass at 250 DAH (2700 GDDs).

comparative_results.comparison_type: Nutrient Internal Efficiency (NIE) across yield levels
comparative_results.practical_significance: Maximum NIEs (713 kg stalk kg⁻¹ N, 5962 kg stalk kg⁻¹ P, 478 kg stalk kg⁻¹ K) occurred at lowest yield levels, indicating nutrient dilution. Minimum NIEs (623 kg stalk kg⁻¹ N, 3649 kg stalk kg⁻¹ P, 320 kg stalk kg⁻¹ K) occurred at highest yield levels, indicating nutrient accumulation or luxury consumption.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Reciprocal Internal Efficiency (RIE) across yield levels
comparative_results.practical_significance: RIE values for 80-160 Mg ha⁻¹ yield range: 1.3–1.6 kg N, 0.21–0.28 kg P, and 2.4–3.2 kg K per Mg of stalk produced. These values are higher than some previous studies, attributed to higher yield levels.

comparative_results.comparison_type: Nutrient content and ratios across plant components
comparative_results.practical_significance: Dry leaves had lower nutrient content (N, P, K) and broader N:P (18:1) and N:K ratios compared to tops and stalks. Tops accumulated greatest amounts of nutrients (~60% N, ~75% P, ~80% K) and maintained more balanced N:P (6:1) and N:K (0.5:1) ratios, especially in high-yielding systems.

geographic_details.coordinates: Site 1: 22° 35′ S; 47° 37′ W (Piracicaba); Site 2: 21° 47′ S; 47° 11′ W (Santa Cruz das Palmeiras); Site 3: 20° 46′ S; 48° 45′ W (Severínia)

climate_characteristics.climate_classification: Tropical (implied by soil types and region)

precipitation_patterns.Site 1: 1,862 mm (1.5-fold higher than 81-year average of 1,230 mm)
precipitation_patterns.Site 2: 1,691 mm (1.3-fold greater than 29-year average of 1,330 mm)
precipitation_patterns.Site 3: 1,310 mm (slightly superior than 17-year average of 1,266 mm)
precipitation_patterns.general_trend: Above local average during sugarcane growing season (12 months)

climate_characteristics.gdd_calculation_method: Growing degree days (GDDs) were calculated using a base temperature of 10 °C (Allison et al., 2007).

soil_properties.soil_classification: Site 1: Typic Hapludox; Site 2 & 3: Typic Eutrustox (Soil Taxonomy, 2014)
soil_properties.texture: Clay content (0-20 cm): Site 1: 510 g kg⁻¹; Site 2: 630 g kg⁻¹; Site 3: 299 g kg⁻¹ (indicating clayey soils)
soil_properties.organic_matter: Soil organic C (0-20 cm): Site 1: 23 g dm⁻³; Site 2: 17 g dm⁻³; Site 3: 9 g dm⁻³

chemical_properties.Available_P_0_20cm: Site 1: 29 mg dm⁻³; Site 2: 8 mg dm⁻³; Site 3: 28 mg dm⁻³
chemical_properties.Available_K_0_20cm: Site 1: 33 mg dm⁻³; Site 2: 27 mg dm⁻³; Site 3: 12 mg dm⁻³
chemical_properties.Exchangeable_Ca_0_20cm: Site 1: 4.3 mmolc dm⁻³; Site 2: 49 mmolc dm⁻³; Site 3: 18 mmolc dm⁻³
chemical_properties.Exchangeable_Mg_0_20cm: Site 1: 13 mmolc dm⁻³; Site 2: 13 mmolc dm⁻³; Site 3: 9 mmolc dm⁻³
chemical_properties.Exchangeable_Al_0_20cm: Site 1: 6 mmolc dm⁻³; Site 2: 0 mmolc dm⁻³; Site 3: 1 mmolc dm⁻³
chemical_properties.CEC_pH7_0_20cm: Site 1: 95 mmolc dm⁻³; Site 2: 91 mmolc dm⁻³; Site 3: 49 mmolc dm⁻³
chemical_properties.Sulfur_0_20cm: Site 1: 29 mg dm⁻³; Site 2: 8 mg dm⁻³; Site 3: 28 mg dm⁻³

land_use_context.management_intensity: High-yielding systems, adoption of green cane management, precision agriculture tools (Site 3).
land_use_context.historical_context: Site 1 had a long history of annual applications of vinasse and press mud.
sustainability_metrics: Green cane management system (no burning) contributes to C sequestration and reduced fertilizer needs.

varieties_cultivars: SP89-1115 (Site 1: early ripening, average yield potential, sucrose, fiber)
SP81-3250 (Site 2: middle ripening, high sugarcane yield potential, sucrose, fiber)
RB855453 (Site 3: early ripening, high yield potential, sucrose, average fiber)

application_methods: Manual band application over straw layer, 20 cm from plant row (N, P, K)
Foliar application (HSS and HSS+N treatments at Site 3)

irrigation.system_type: Rainfed (implied by high precipitation and lack of irrigation details)

other_practices.tillage: Conventional tillage (plowing, disking, harrowing, furrowing) performed every 6 years.
organic_amendments: Sugarcane straw (dry leaves and tops) left on soil surface (green cane management)

input_rates.fertilizer_N_P_K: Varied by site and treatment (see management_practices.fertilization.rates)

output_measurements.nutrient_content_in_biomass: N: 86-425 kg ha⁻¹, P: 10-79 kg ha⁻¹, K: 159-866 kg ha⁻¹ (aboveground)

efficiency_metrics.nutrient_internal_efficiency_NIE: N: 623-713 kg stalk kg⁻¹ N; P: 3649-5962 kg stalk kg⁻¹ P; K: 320-478 kg stalk kg⁻¹ K (varying with yield level)
efficiency_metrics.reciprocal_internal_efficiency_RIE: N: 1.3-1.6 kg N Mg⁻¹ stalk; P: 0.21-0.28 kg P Mg⁻¹ stalk; K: 2.4-3.2 kg K Mg⁻¹ stalk (varying with yield level)

study_timeline.end_date: August 2013 (approx. end of Site 3 ratoon cycle)
data_collection_schedule: Plant sampling: 4 times per ratoon cycle (e.g., 139, 178, 235, 330 DAH for Site 1)
study_timeline.monitoring_frequency: Periodic plant sampling, biweekly weather monitoring.

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Sigmoid growth curve (lag, exponential-linear, stationary phases)
peak_periods: Exponential-linear phase (135-270 DAH) for rapid growth
minimum_periods: Lag phase (0-135 DAH) for slow growth

seasonal_variations.seasonal_pattern: Linear accumulation during exponential-linear phase, followed by a decrease in N and K content in mid-Phase III (ripening).
peak_periods: Mid-Phase II to early Phase III

long_term_trends.sustainability_implications: Green cane management (straw retention) can lead to long-term benefits for C sequestration and reduced fertilizer needs. Replenishing stalk nutrient removal is essential for sustaining high yields.

variability_characterization.inter_annual_variability: Data synthesized from different growing seasons (2009/2010 and 2012/2013), but not explicitly analyzed as inter-annual variability.

spatial_variability.soil_properties_differences: Site 1 (low pH, base saturation, high Al), Site 2 (low K, P), Site 3 (high fertility, high yield)

methodological_strengths: Comprehensive data synthesis from multiple field sites and years (n=102).
Detailed characterization of biomass and nutrient partitioning across different plant components.
Application of non-linear models for growth and nutrient accumulation.
Validation of models against previously published studies.
Focus on green cane management system, relevant to current agricultural practices.
methodological_limitations: Nutrient ratios (N:P and N:K) were investigated only at harvest, limiting insights into in-season nutrient dynamics and management.
Lack of specific instrumentation models and detailed quality control procedures beyond general method references.
No explicit calculation of statistical power for all analyses.
data_quality_assessment.data_completeness: High, extensive quantitative data provided for biomass, nutrient content, and efficiencies.

representativeness.spatial_representativeness: Good, with three sites covering different soil conditions within a major sugarcane region.
representativeness.temporal_representativeness: Limited to first ratoon cycle, but includes data from different growing seasons.
representativeness.system_representativeness: Representative of green cane management systems in tropical regions.

uncertainty_sources: Variability in soil nutrient status and historical management practices across sites.
Potential for nutrient remobilization or foliar emissions affecting nutrient content at harvest.
validation_evidence: Model validation against external datasets (Shukla et al., 2009; Oliveira et al., 2010; Schultz et al., 2010).

key_methodological_references: AOAC International (2006) for plant tissue analysis.
van Raij et al. (2001), Nelson and Sommers (1996), Gee and Bauder (1986) for soil analysis.
Allison et al. (2007) for GDD calculation.
Ciampitti and Vyn (2012) for NIE/RIE calculation.
Soil Survey Staff (2014) for soil classification.
comparative_studies: Sugarcane yield: Gava et al. (2005), Prado and Pancelli (2008), Oliveira (2011), Amaral and Molin (2013), Fortes et al. (2013), Otto et al. (2013), Rossato et al. (2013), Thorburn et al. (2011), Coale et al. (1993), McCray et al. (2014).
N content: Wood et al. (1996), Oliveira et al. (2010), Franco et al. (2011).
P content: Rakkiyappan et al. (2007), Shukla et al. (2009), Oliveira et al. (2010).
K content: Coale et al. (1993), Shukla et al. (2009).
Biomass accumulation: Machado et al. (1982), Coale et al. (1993), Inman-Bamber et al. (2002), Gava et al. (2005).
Nutrient ratios (N:P, N:K): Ciampitti and Vyn (2014), Sadras (2006).
Nutrient Internal Efficiencies: Setiyono et al. (2010), Ciampitti et al. (2013).
Reciprocal Internal Efficiencies: Silva and Casagrande (1983), Gopalasundaram et al. (2012).
literature_integration.theoretical_framework: Nutrient imbalances, nutrient use efficiency (NUE), nutrient partitioning, nutrient stoichiometry, internal efficiencies (NIE, RIE), DRIS (Diagnosis and Recommendation Integrated System), N replacement concept.
data_sources: UNICA (2015) for Brazilian sugarcane cultivated area.
benchmarking_data: Yields and nutrient contents compared against various regional and international sugarcane studies.
N:P and N:K ratios compared against other crop types (corn, oilseed, cereal, legume).

extraction_metadata.data_richness_assessment: The paper is rich in quantitative data, particularly on nutrient content, partitioning, and efficiencies across different yield levels and plant components. Detailed soil and climate data are also provided.
potential_ambiguities: Specific instrumentation models were not provided.
Exact analytical precision or detection limits were not specified.
The term 'optimal water conditions' is used in discussion, but the study sites experienced above-average precipitation, implying rainfed conditions rather than controlled irrigation.
extraction_limitations: Lack of in-season nutrient dynamics data for ratios, as noted by the authors.
No specific details on pest or disease management.
recommended_validation_checks: Verify specific values from Table 2 and Table 3 against the original paper for exact match, especially for ranges and means.
Cross-reference cited methodological papers for deeper understanding of analytical procedures if needed.

enhancements_added: Study duration in years refined in 'research_methodology.temporal_scope.study_duration_years'.
Treatment counts for Site 1 and Site 2 clarified in 'research_methodology.sample_design.controls_and_treatments'.
Mean values for aboveground N, P, K content added to 'quantitative_findings.primary_measurements'.
GDD ranges added to biomass accumulation phases in 'quantitative_findings.temporal_patterns'.
Explicit limitation regarding in-season nutrient ratio data added to 'data_quality_assessment.methodological_limitations'.
Ambiguity regarding 'optimal water conditions' added to 'extraction_metadata.potential_ambiguities'.
areas_enriched: Research methodology (temporal scope, sample design, analytical methods)
Data quality assessment (methodological limitations, potential ambiguities)
enhancement_summary.enhancement_justification: Enhancements were made to provide more granular detail, clarify ambiguities, and ensure a more complete and scientifically precise representation of the original paper's content, particularly in areas of quantitative data, methodological specifics, and contextual information.

validation_quality.validator_notes: The original Stage 1A extraction was already of high quality, with very few inaccuracies. The validation process primarily focused on enhancing completeness and adding finer scientific detail, particularly in methodological descriptions, quantitative data presentation, and contextual elements like GDDs and specific treatment counts. All identified opportunities for enhancement were addressed, resulting in a significantly richer and more precise extraction.

results.paper_id: Nutrient Partitioning and Stoichiometry in Unburnt Sugarcane Ratoon at Varying Yield Levels
